1.question: Do you want to oblige a developer to disclose the source code of his/her own software, if such software includes your code?
1.yes: You may oblige other people to disclose source code of their own software if such software includes your own source code.
1.no: You may provide other people a freedom to solve: to disclose or not disclose the source code of their own software.

2.question: Do you want to allow a developer do not disclose his/her source code in some cases?
2.yes: E.g. your source code is an library, and you really do not want to oblige users to disclose source code of that projects which used your library as an component.
2.no: You would like to oblige users disclose source code of their software in all cases if your code is included in their software.

3.question: Do you want to add formulations about your patent rights on the code?
3.yes: Your license will contain formulations about patents and patent rights on your code.
3.no: Your license will not contain formulations about patents and patent rights on your code.

4.question: Must a developer disclose source code of his/her software in case of its distribution via any network (including server-based software)?
4.yes: If user software (which includes your source code as an component) is a web-based software, you may oblige such user to disclose the source code of such software.
4.no: If user software (which includes your source code as an component) is a web-based software, you do not want to oblige such user to disclose the source code of such software.

5.question: Do you extremely need a license containing all applicable conditions for many use cases in short form?
5.yes: Some licenses have a short text, which is enough for many use cases by other people. But they do not usually cover specific use cases (e.g. trademark and patents rights).
5.no: You would like to cover by license text as many use cases as possible. And a long license text is not problem for you and your users.

6.question: Must a developer clearly specify changes of your code in case of its modification?
6.yes: If somebody changes your code, he/she needs to state such changes (in any form, e.g. changelog, comments in source code, additional documentation file, etc.).
6.no: If somebody changes your code, he/she is not obliged to state such changes (in any form, e.g. changelog, comments in source code, etc.).

7.question: Must a developer include your copyright and license info of your code in his/her software, if he/she includes your code in it?
7.yes: If anyone uses your code, he/she is obliged to inform other users that he/she really use your code by providing the info about your copyright and license related to such your source code. See a link about:license in your Firefox browser as an examplle.
7.no: If anyone uses your code, he/she may (but is not obliged) to inform other users that he/she really use your code by providing the info about your copyright and license related to such your source code.

8.question: Do you want to specify possible means of your code usage in details?
8.yes: Your license will contain the info about possible means of your code usage (e.g. to use, merge, distribute, etc.)
8.no: Your license will not contain the info about possible means of your code usage (e.g. to use, merge, distribute, etc.)

9.question: Do you want to specify that you really allow to use your code in commercial and/or non-commercial purposes?
9.yes: Your license will clearly inform your users that they are allowed to use your code in both purposes (commercial or non-commercial).
9.no: Your license will not inform your users that they are allowed to use your code in both purposes (commercial or non-commercial).

10.question: Do you want to specify rules of your name usage to endorse or promote products derived from your source code?
10.yes: Your license will contain the info how to use your name to endorse or promote products derived from your source code.
10.no: Your license will not contain such information.

11.question: Do you want to specify that you do not grant any trademark right?
11.yes: Your license will clearly inform that you do not grant any trademark rights on your source code.
11.no: Your license will not inform that you do not grant any trademark rights on your source code.

12.question: Do you want to oblige a developer to specify changes of your code in case of its modification by him/her?
12.yes: If somebody changes your code, he/she needs to state such changes (in any form, e.g. changelog, comments in source code, additional documentation file, etc.).
12.no: If somebody changes your code, he/she is not obliged to state such changes (in any form, e.g. changelog, comments in source code, etc.).

13.question: Must a developer defend you from lawsuits in case of usage by him/her your code in commercial purposes?
13.yes: You may oblige users to defend you and your contributors to hold you from lawsuits.
13.no: Your license will not contain such protection.

14.question: Do you need to receive an express grant of patent rights from your contributors to you?
14.yes: If you will receive patches and other contributions to your source code, you would like to receive patent rights from owners of such patches and contributions.
14.no: There is no necessity to receive patent rights from owners of patches and contributions to your software.
